editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: A PRIMER for the Schollers and Doctors of EUROPE, But especially to them in and about the (called) Two famous Universities in England, Oxford and Cambridge, To them, and every of them, whether Tutors or Schollers, Batchellors and Masters of Arts, Batchellours of Divinity and Doctors of Divinity, or to any other Member of that Body, that hath sprung from these the two, so called, well heads of Divinity, either such who keeps their station and trading there, or such who have learned their Arts, Sciences and trades there, and now improves them to their best advantage in the Nation of England, or elsewhere.

Being a brief rehearsal of some of the words and terms which have for several ages been used, and now are used in their chief Schools of learning, and Universities, contained in their seven Liberal Arts, i. e. Grammer, Logick, Rhetorick, Musick, Arithmetick, Geometrie, Astronomy, together with that you call Geographie, Ethicks, Physicks, Metaphisicks, Theologie and Medicine.
By George Fox.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Simmons at the Bull and Mouth near Aldersgate, 1659.

div.head: TO THE READER:
div.p:
HEre the Enlightened Reader whose eyes are opened with the Light, may discern whether or nay you be not all in the wisdom of mans teaching that teacheth words, which all your seven Arts and Sciences, terms and names comes from; and what was the root they all sprung from, was it not from the wisdom of man which is below, and the words that it doth teach? This is written to you to examin and search out if you be among that number which have that spirit that searcheth all things, yea, the deep things of God, 1 Cor. 2.10. but if they have not that spirit, to examine and search with, and with it to read this Primmer, and to answer to every particular thing and word in it contained, according to the true and full intent of every particular querie herein inserted, then let all Grammarians, Logicians, Rhetoritians, Musicians, Arithmeticians, Geometricians, and Astronomers, Physicians, Tutors, Schollers, Batchellors of Arts▪ Masters of Arts, Batchellors of Divinity, and Doctors of Divinity, Chancellors and Vice-Chancellors, or any other member of this Body that hath sprung from these two Well-heads, think and judge themselves to be among the number, which the spirit of Truth
hath spoken of in Isaiah 29.14. Therefore behold I will proceed to do a marvellous work amongst this people, even a marvellous work and a wonder, for the wisdom of their wise men shall perish, and the understanding of their prudent men shall be hid.

These seven Arts, Names, Terms and words have been their holes and dens where they have been hidden, and there they have hid themselves from the ignorant, These Queries are to call them out into the field, that every one may see their garment, that they may give answer to every one of these words, names and things, and their root and first Authour of them, let them come out now to little children, these great Champions which hath been clad with Goliahs armour, little Davids are risen, and with their slings and their bags full of stones: So this is a call for every uncircumcised Philistine to come forth into the open field and there to be tried with little Davids, who have the bags and the slings, and the stones, which is the power of God.

div.head: Ye Schollers and Doctors ansewr me these QƲERIES.
div.p: 1. WHat is Grammer, and what is the word Grammar in it self?
2. What is a Noun in it self, and what was the first rise of it, and who was the first Author of it, and by whom?
3. What is a Pronoun in it self, and what is the word in it self, and who was the first Author of it, and by whom it came?
4. What is a Verb, and the word Verb, and out from whom had it its root, and by whom?

5. What is a Participle, and what is it in it self, and by whom came, and out of what ground, and why are these declined, and why is the word called declined, who was the first rise and author of it, and by whom it came.

6. And why is the word called Adverb, and what is an Adverb, the word it self, and who was its rise, and why do you call the word Conjunction, and who was its rise? and why the word Preposition, and who was its rise? And who was the Author of the word Interjection, and what are these two words in themselves, and whether or no these are not come up by the art of men and invention?

7. What is the word Vowel in it self, and what was the word Vowel, and what is the word Dipthong, and who was the Author of these, and where are they called by any such names in Scripture, so who was the Author of these names, and who gave them, and what are these names in themselves, and of themselves, and came they not from the art of men, yea, or nay?

8. What is the word Substantive in it self? and what is the word Adj •••• ve in it self? and what is the Article in it self? And what is the word Termination in its self, and what was the first author, and ground and rise of these words, and whether or nay they are not in the art and wit, out of that nature which hath been since the fall?

9. And why do you call the words Nominative, Genitive, Dative, Accusative, Vocative, and Ablative, and what are these words in themselves, and from what root had these words their rise, and all the rest above mentioned, and what was it that figured forth all these words above mentioned, and who was the first Author of them?
10. And why do ye call the word masculine, feminine, and neuter, and epicine? And what was the ground of these words in themselves, what are they?
11. And why do you use the word declention, and what is in the word it self, and what was its root?

12 And why the words positive, comparative, and superlative, and what be these words, as they are words, of what author and root came they from, and who gave them these tearms first, who was the first rise, and by whom?
13. And why these words, primative, demonstrative, relative, derivative, Possessive, indefinite, reciprocal, and what be these words themselves, and what was the root?
14 And why the words simple, and why compound, and what is the word and its root, and its author?
15. And why the word; mood and tence? and why the word personal and impersonal, and why deponent, and what is these words, and what was the author and root and ground of them?
16. Why the indicative, imperative, optative, potential, subjunctive, and infinitive, and what are these words in themselves, and what was their root and author?
17 Why the words presenttence, preterimperfectence, preterperfectence, preterpluperfectence, and futuretence, what are in these words themselves, and what was their root and author?
18. And why the words gerunds and supines, and what are these words, and what is the author of them, and what was their root?

19. And what are these words, transitive, and intransitive, and inceptive? why these words, and what is their root, and how came they first forth, and who was their first author, come ye that say ye are learned men, answer?
20 And what are these words orthographie, etymologie, Syntaxis, prosodia, and what are these words themselves?

21. Why semi-vowels, liquids, mutes? and why these words
ortheopia, traulism, pleteasm, isconites? and what be these words, and what be the root of them, and of whom were they first learned?

22. And why a comma, a colon, a period, a parenthesis, introgation, exclamation, and hyphen, species, analogie, anomilie, proper and common, case and gender, collective; and what be the words, and what was their author and root?

23. And why these words fictions, interrogatives, redditives, indefinites, relative, cardinals, ordinals, distributives, partitives, m • ltiplicative, proportional, ponderal, verbal, patrial, gentile, patronimic, deminitive, possessive, denominative material, local, participial, adverbial? and what are all these, and what is the author of them all, and who was he, and what are their roots?

24. And what are these words copulatives, suspensives, disjunctives, causals, discretives, conditionals, exceptives, interrogatives, dubitatives, illatives, continuatives, consessives, adversatives, redditives, electives, diminitives, expletives or completives, prepositives, subjunctives, post positives, encliticals or inclinatives; what are all these words, and what was the author of these words, and who and what are the root, and what are they in themselves?
25. And what are these words apposition and composition, and in them what is your end?
26. And why these words used in a Grammer, prosthesis, epenthesis, Syncope, paragoge, apocope?
27. And what these words di • resis, Synaeresis, metathesis antithesis, or antistaechon, tmesis, enallage, archaismus, metaplasmus, &c?
28. And wherefore these words appositio, Syllepsis, prolepsis, Zeugma, Synthesis, antiptosis, Synecdoche, ellipsis, pleonasmus, asyndeton polyfindeton, anastrophe Synchysis, hypallage, hellenismus?
29 Why accent, transposition, attraction, concision, idiome, what are these words, and from what was their rise?
30. And what be all these termes which you use in your Grammer, spondaeus pyrrhychius, Trochaeus, iambus?
31. And why these words molossus, tribrachus, dactylus, Anapaestus, bacchius, antibacchius, amphimacer, amphibrachus?

32 And what are these words Synalaepha, eclipsis, synaeresis, Diaeresi •
and caesura?

33. What are these words, Monocolon, dicolon, tricolon, policolon,
and what was the root of these words, and what are the words?

And why Distrophon, tristrophon, tetrastrophon, Pentrastroph •• , hemistichon distichon, tetrasticon, hexastichon, eteestichon, emarostichon? And what are these words, and who was the author of these words, and from what ground and root came they, and whether they were given forth from the spirit of God, or the words of mans wisdom, answer ye that are accounted learned wise men, There is three feet for you to stand upon them if you can?

div.head: Logick.
div.p: WHat is the word Logick in it self?
2. What a theam, a single theam, and a compound theam? what is a universal, and what a special theam, and what is abstract and concrete?
3. What is an individium, and an individium vagum, invidium accidental, and substantial, and what is a categorie?

4. And what the word praedicable, and why five praedicables, genus, species, differentia, proprium, accidens? what are these words, and what was the root and author of them? and what is genus s • mmum and genus intermedium? what are these words, and their author and root, and whether or no all these words are not in the art of man, and the words of mans wisdom, yea or nay? and why species intermedia, and what is it?

5. Why the word praedicament, what are these words which you call ten praedicaments, substantia, quantitas, qualitas, relativa, actio, passio, quando ubi situs, habitus? what are these words and what are their root; are they not the wisdom of words of mans wisdom, and what are these words, collateral, identity of disjunctive subordination, causal indentity, cohesive identity, and accidental identity? and the words subordinate, co-ordinate, and what generical disjunction, specifical distinction, and individual distinction, and what is the ground these words came from, and their author and root, and who, and by whom.
6. why the words, continuae quantitas, and discreta quantitas and these words what are they, and the root what is it, and theirs was whom.
7. Why the word Propositio, Subjectum, and Atributum, and indefinite? and why Subcontrariae and Subalternae, what be these words, and what was their ground, and who was their Author?

8. And what are these words Propositio, Categorica & Con
•… ingent • s, what are these words, and what was their root, and who was their Author, and by whom came they?

9. And why the words Simplex per accedens, & per contrapositionem? and what were these words, and their author who was, and what was he? and why the word propositio, Hypothetica, and what is the word, and what is the Author, and what is the root?

10. What is a Syllogism, and why these tearms in a Syllogism, Major, Minor, and Medius, and who was the Author of them, and what was the root of them, and what is the word Termini, and what was its root, and from what did all these spring above mentioned, you who say you are learned men, bring out your arguments and strong reasons, now in the day, that all things may be tried, and the roots from whence all words comes, the vvords that are spoken from the vvisdome of men, as it hath taught them, and the vvords that are spoken from the holy Ghost?

11. What is an accident? 12. What is the Efficient cause? 13. What is the Emanative cause; 14. What is the active cause? 15. What is the Immanent cause? 16. What is the Transient cause? 17. What is causae per se? 18. What is causa per accidens? 19. What is the Procatarctick cause?
12. What is a Subject and vvhat is an Adjunct? and vvhat is Analogy, vvhat is Identity, What is Numerical identity, and vvhat is Subordinate, and Co-ordinate Identity?
21. What is Privation, vvhat is a Synonyma or Univoke.

22. What is a Hemonyma? What is a Predicate, vvhat is Hypothetica, vvhat is a Disjunctive an Adversative, a Relative? & vvhat is the cause of an Accident, & the cause of all Accidents, & vvhat is the cause of all these Causes? and vvhat is the cause of all these Words, and vvhat is the root, and vvhether or no they be not superfluous, and from the vvisdom of the flesh, and vvhether or no the holie Ghost doth not speak in plainer vvords then these be, and vvhether or no they vvere not from the vvisdome of the Heathens, and they vvere not their root, ansvver yea or nay?

23. What is a Contingent Enuntiation, and vvhat is definit ••
vvhat are all these vvords, and vvhether they did proceed from the darknesse, and not from the holie Ghost, and who vvas the author of these vvords, and vvhat vvas their first ground and root, bring it forth?

24. And again, vvhich vvas once queried before, vvhat is a Syllogism, vvhat is the major, vvhat is the minor, and vvhat is the medius, vvhat are those vvords everie one in particular as they are in themselves, and their author and root, vvhat is it? and vvho vvas he?

25. What is Barbara, Celarent, Darii, Cesare, Camestres fastino, Baroco, Darapti felapton, difamis, datisi, Bocardo, ferison? What be all these vvords, and vvhether the Wisdome of the flesh vvas not their author, and the root What was it?
26. What is an Induction, an Etymeme, what is an Hypothetical Syllogism? from whence comes these words, and what be they, and who was the author of them, and what was the ground they first rose from?

27. What is a Categorical Syllogism, what is a Dilemma, what is a Sorite and what is a Dialectical fylogism what are all those words, and who was their first rise, and from what power came they, from light or darknesse, yea or nay? and who was their first author and rise, Heathens or Saints, ansvver them?

28. What is a Probleme, vvhat is a Concentaneous, and discentaneous argument? what is axiome, what is Thesis, and what is Hypothesis? what be all these words, and Who was the first sette • of them up?

29. What is Sophisim? what is Amphybolie? what is Elench? what is Analitical, Syntheical, Categorematical, Sincaregorematecal? what are all these words, and what was the author of them, the wisdom of the flesh or the wisdome of God? what was the ground and root they arose from, and what is the word Syllogism, who was the first inventer of it, was it from the inspiration or invention, or doth invention bring men into reason, or destroy it, or doth any thing bring men into reason but that which doth inspire?
30. What is Abstract, and what is Concrete and Subaltern, and Method?

31. What is a Proposition, Antecedent, Consequent, transmutative, Esential Integral, homogeneum Heterogeneum, what be every one of these words, and what be the root, or what is the rise, and what is that
which gives them their faith? • nd whether or no they are words that must be fulfilled & cannot be broken, and if so, what is it that fulfille, and who was the author of them, and first giver of them forth? Answer me if you be in that which is before words was given forth, or else let your mouth be stopped; is there not a ground where the words of confusion comes forth, is there not words that mans wisdome doth teach? and what is that which distinguisheth that teaching, from the teaching which teacheth the words of truth, yea or nay? and if it be so, if you become into that, then Answer me.
32. What is a Canon a Concomitant a Cohaesive, an Hypostatical a Causal, an Illustration, what a definite, an Indefinite, what an Equivalent?

33. What are all these words, Paronima, comcominative, reciprocall, Typical, Sacramental, Exclusive, Exceptive, Co-operative? who was the first author of all these words, and what was their first ground and root, and what are all these words in themselves, and whose were they, and are they; are they given forth from the invention and wisdome of men, or were the spirit of God the root of them? me ye answer, if you understand your own body; what body are you, and from what body these come from, the body of Christ yea or nay? And whether that which doth not come from the body of Christ, and is not of him, and from him, will not reason destroy and put an end to, and will not it destroy reason, that reason doth destroy and make an end of, Answer me this, ye • or no?

div.head: Some Questions about Rhetorick.
div.p: 1. VVHat is Rhetorick?
2 What is a Trope in which it is said that two things are to be considered, the species and the affections? and why are the species of Tropes 4?
1. A Metonimy, an Irony, a Metaphor and a Synecdoche, what be all these words, and what is the ground from whence all these words, and what are all these words in themselves, as they are words?

3. What are these five words which you call the affections? a Trope, Cataechresis, Hyperbole, Metalepsis, Litotes, Allegorie? from whence came in these words, and what their root, and what be in these words, and from what spirit did they come?

4. And what is Antonomasia, Onomatopaeia, Antiphrasis, Charientismus, Astismus, Sarcasmus, Paraemia, Anigma, and several more who was the root of them all, and these words, what are they? and what was the wisdome they came from?
5. What is a figure which you say in Greek is Scema, and what is this word, and are your figures to be fulfilled, and are they given forth from that spirit that gave forth Scriptures?
6. What is this figure Metaplasmus, of which is said there are four kinds?
7. And what is Synalaepha, Ectlipsis, which is called the first kind?
8. And what Prosthesis, Aphaeresis, Epenthesis Cyncope, paragoge, Apocope, which in your Grammer ye call the figures of a word?

9. What is Diaeresis, Synaeresis, which is called the third kind, and your fourth kind is called T • nesis, Metathesis, Antithesis, Diastole, Systole, from whence had you all these words? what was their ground and rise and root, was not it earthly, and did not i •• wisdome teach them to speak them forth, are they the words of Scripture or of the Spirit that gave them forth (that is) the Scripture, or are they words that is to be confounded with that spirit?

10. What be these figures, Epizeuxis, Anadiplosis Anaphora, Epistrophe, Symploce, Epanalepsis, Epanados, Paranomisia, Poliptoton? and from whence comes all these words, and what is every one of these words, and what is the root of every one of these words, and what is it they did proceed from?

11. And what are these figures, Climax, Antanaclasis, Antithesis Ploce, Paregmenon, Synaeceiosis, Oxymozon, Synthesis, Hendiadis, Hypallage, Hyperhaton, Ellipsis, pleonasmus, Asyndeton, Poly Syndet • n Hysterologia, Zeugma, Hellenismus, Antiptosis; and these above you call the figure of a word?

VVhat be all these words in themselves, and what was the root they did proceed from; and from whence had that its root, and who was the first author of them all; was he in the wisdome of God, or in his own invention, or the wisdome below; yea or
nay? so answer me, how came they up, and by what and whom they came?

12 And what are these which you call the figures of a sentence, Ecphonesis, Periphrasis, Parenthesis, Epiphon • ma, Parathesis, Diatyposis, Synonymia, Horismos, Parrhesia, Apostopesis, Apostrophe Paradiastole, Parechesis, Erotesis, Hypotyposis, Metabasis?

And what be all these words? and what is the root of them all? and what be they all every particular word as they are in themselves? and what did they spring from? that will change, or from that which doth not change? And you say a figure in a sentence is either in Logismo or Dialogismo, what is Logismus and Dialogismus?

What is Apostrophe and Prosopopoeia? and what is Aporia Anacaenosis, Prolepsis, Hypophora, Epitrope, Synchoraesis? These words what be they all? and who was the first beginner of them? were they invented, or imagined, or revealed by the Spirit of God, or are they words that make men wise in the wisdom of the world, or make them wise in the wisdom of God, yea or nay? or were they given • orth from the wisdom of God, yea or nay? or from the inventer? Answer, that things may come out to the light; what was their Author and Root, and from whence had they their rise?

13. What is Metonymia Efficientis, Metonymia Effecti, Subjecti, Adjuncti, Metonymia Materiae, Metonymia Instrumenti, Antecedentis, Metonymia Consequentis, Metonymia Conexi and Metonymia Finis? and Metonymia formae? what be these words? and from whence? from the Ayre or from the life, are they the words that are put into the mouth by the Spirit of God, or are they words that mens wisdom doth teach; So Answer me from what ground and Root they sprang?

14. What is Synecdoche Specei, Synecdoche partis, Synecdoche, Generis, Synecdoche totius, Synecdoche Numeri? And from whence had you all these words, their rise, and what is their rise? and wh t is the rise? and what be the words and their ground? and wheth • r or no it is not from that, that keeps people under a cloud from th • t which should give them an understandin • , in the ignorance, wh • re wisdoms teaching hears words which is earthly, and others l • arning that be earthly and not spiritual? is this yea or nay so?

div.head: Questions, concerning some of your termes, which you use in one of the seven Arts, called Arithmetick.
div.p: 1. WH • t is Arithmetick, what is the extraction of roots, and what is the greater Diagonal, the lesser Diagonal.

2. What is the square root, the Cube root, the squared sq • ar • s, Sursolids squares of Cubes, squares of Cubes, Second surd solids, squares of squared sq •• res. Cubes of Cubes, squares of Surd Solids, Surd Solids of Surd Solids?

3. What are these words Algebra, and what is a right lined Parellelipedon and an Inaequaliter, and what the greater and the lesser Segment or Quotient, who was the first Author of all these words, and what are their root, what hath born them, and these words, what are they, and whether or no they were the words that did proceed from the life of God, or the ear • hly wisdom that hath taught them below; so the words in themselves what are they, and who was the first Author of them, and whether or no they be sutable to the life, or that dark airy inventing part that prisons it?

div.head: Some Questions about your Art which you call Geometrie.
div.p: 1. WHat is Geometry?
2. What is a point?
3. What is a line; and what is its limits?
4. What is a superficies, and what are its extreams?
5. What is an Angle, a plain Angle an obtuse Angle, and an Acute Angl • ?
6. What is Perpendicular?
7. What is a figure, what is a circle or circumference.
8. What is a center, a Diameter, and what the Diameter of a circle, and what a Semi-circle, and what the Section of a circle?
9. What are right lined SIDED and many SIDED figures?
10. What is a Tryangle, and what an Equilateral Tryangle?
11. What is an Isoscoles, a Scalenium an Orthogonium, an Ambligonium and an Oxigonium.
12. What is a Quadrat a Rhombus, a Rhomboides?
13. What are all your four SIDED figures called Trapezia or tables?
14. What is a Paralell, and Parallelogram?
15. What is a spaericall and a Gonicall body and what is a Teres.

16. What are Globes, Piramis, a Column and a Cilindrus, &c? What be all these termes and names and words, and whether or no they be not words of mens wisdom, art and inventions, that he hath sought out since the transgression, answer me if any of you, have the measuring line, by which the earth is measured, and the waters with this line can ye measure? And where do the Scriptures of truth that speaks of measuring speak such words, termes and phrases as is above mentioned, and what be every one of these words, and what be every of their rootes, and whether or no they were not in the imagination? for the branches you have discovered, and they are to be gathered in every town and and street, and Allyes you may gather bundles of them, therefore the root that hath born and brought forth all these expressions and phrases what is it? and what be the words?

And came they from the wisdom that is below, earthly, sensual and Devillish, (that doth teach) or from the wisdom which is from above that the world is comprehended withall, which was before the world began which measures, comprehends time, age, Sea, and Land, and fathoms the world as a span, whose wisdom speaks; and of her children is justified who love her, and are nourished and cherished by her.

div.head: Some Questions of your termes of Geographie.
div.p: 1. VVHat is Geographie?
2. How is it the eye and light of History? and how thereby do other Mathematical sciences especially profit those that are studious in Philosophy contemplative (as you say of them?)
3. What is a Globe, and what the Globe of the earth and water is?
4. What is the general part of Geographie? and what is the special part?
5. What is its absolute part? and vvhat is its comparitive part?
6. What is a real Globe of the earth? and vvhat is a representive or painted one?
7. What are the accidents of affections of the earthly Globe?

8. What is a Peninsula or Chersoness? What vvas the first that gave all these names? and ansvver these things every one in their particular, and vvhat vvas the root that they sprung from, vvhat be all these vvords as they are vvords, for the branches have discovered themselves, therefore vvhat be the root? Ansvver me.
9. What is an Isthmus? And vvhat a Promontorie?

10. What are these imaginary parts of the earth, vvhich not being at all, must yet be supposed to be, vvhich you call the circle immutable, as the Aequator and the cirles mutable, as the Meridian and Horrizon?
11. What are the lesser imaginary Circles, as the Tropical of Cancer and Capricorn, and the Polar either Arctique or Antartick and the parellel or Aequidistant?

12. What are the five zones? as vvhat is the Torride zone, the Frigid zones, and the temperate zones? Ansvver me vvhat be all these words as they are vvords in themselves? And vvhat be all the root of these vvords? And from vvhat stock do they spring? for your branches have shevved themselves forth; & vvho was the first Author of these vvords? A heathen, a transgressor, or a Saint? • nd vvhether or no they are vvords brought forth by your ovvn
imaginations and inventions out of the life; so answer me every word as they are in themselves, and the root and author of them, and whether they have not all come from the wisdome below, which is earthly.
13. What are the artificial Parallels?
14. What is a Climat?
15. What is a rational, and what a sensible Horizon?
16. What are the Aphiscy Priscy Xeterosty, and what the Antieci Perieci and Antipodes?

17. What is a Digit? who was the first inventer of these words, what was his name? from whence had he his rase and his wisdome, and what are all these words above mentioned in themselves; and from what ground did they come, what is the root of every one of these themselves, and what are they in themselves, and do they proceed from the spirit of God, and the holy Ghosts teaching, or the wisdome of mans teaching, which is below, earthly? Answer me if the mouth be opened with that which comprehends roots, words, grounds, centers, sentences and branches?

div.head: The termes of Musick.
div.p: Large Flats
Long
Brief Sharps
Sembrif
Minom
Crochat
Quaver
Semi quaver

VVho was the inventor of all these words, and who was their author, and what be every one of these words in themselves and what be every one of their root whose branches hath appeared; answer me this and who was the first rising of them and whether or no they were all given forth from a transgressor or one out of transgression, or one who was taught of the Holy Ghost or from man whose wisdome was below in the transgession?

div.head: Some Questions concerning that you call Astronomie.
div.p: 1. VVHat is a Sphaere or Orbe right or oblique?
2. What is an Axle, and what are Poles?
3. What are the three Axles with their Poles?
4. What is Zodiack and Horizon?
5. What are the two sorts of feigned Circles, and that you call the greater Circles?

And what is the Equinoctial, the Zodiack, the Colures, the Horizon the Milkie cirkle? what be all these words things and names, and words in themselves, and what are the words? and who was their root and author from whence they came, and who was it?
a spiritual man or a transgressor? So what is every word in it selfe, and thing in it selfe, and root that bore it? shall not the root perish, the branch perish, and they that trust, live and shadow themselves in these branches which from the root doth come, perish together with the root and branches; Answer me if that mouth be opened that comprehends and knowes every root, and what branches they bring forth? what is the root of the wisdome of men that will teach words, which words the things of God are not spoken in it; in the words the Holy Ghost teacheth? These things before mentioned answer me, but whether all these words do not come from them that are not covered with the spirit of God, and so be in the dark.
7. What is the Equator, and what a Civil and a natural day?

8. VVhat are equal and unequal hours, and how came particular hours to be given to particular Planets, and what is a Planet? and which is the Suns day; and which Moons day, which Tuesday and which Mars his day, which weddensday or Mercuries day, which Thursday or Jupiters day, which Friday or Ʋenis day, and which Saturday or Saturns day?

9. VVhich is Januaries moneth, which Februaries moneth, which is March his moneth, which Aprils, moneth, which Mays moneth, which Janes, moneth, which Julies, and which Augusts moneth? And why are the other four moneths called September, and not the seventh moneth? October and not the eight moneth? November and not the ninth moneth▪ December and not the tenth moneth? who was the first author, and what was the first root that bore all these things and brought them forth, that the branches hath now appeared in this day, that are seen in the time of day light? who was the inventer of all the words and things Names and these hours, and these Names to dayes and moneths, how have they come up amongst you, that are called Christians, who vvas your Father that taught you them? the Apostles said they had not many fathers, but he had begotten them; vvho was the first father of all these vvords and names and things, ye that professe your selves to be vvise, and learned men and Schollars, and are Novices and fools, ansvver me the root of every one of these branches, vvho vvas it and vvhat vvas he and his place and his abode, vvhether he be in God or in the World? Ansvver me these things and tell me vvhere thou
art, and say here am I, that all people may knovv the habitation and house and the father of all these above mentioned?

10. What are these vvords vvhich you call the twelve signes of the Zodiacke; Aries, Taurus: Gimini: Cancer: Leo: Ʋirgo: Libra: Scorpius: Sagitarius: Capricornus: Aquarius and Pisces? And hovv came they to rule these parts of the body according to your Almanacks?
11. And vvhat is an Ecclips, the Dragons head and the Dragons Tall?
12. Whats Trine, whats a Quartile and vvhat a Sextil Aspect?
13. What is the Conjunction, and vvhat is the Opposition of Planets?
14. What are the twelve houses of Heaven, vvhich the Genethialicks or Mathematicians do so diligently take notice of in generation?

15. What is a Horoscope, vvhat be all these vvords? have they not proceeded all from the transgressors root vvhich lives in the earth and the Ayre and in the imaginary magick art, Witchcraft, Sorceries, Devinations, vvho vvas your first father of them, of all these vvords, names and things, did they proceed from the transgressor, or did they proceed from that which vvas before the daies, Stars, Sun & Moon vvas? And which doth proceed from that which commands Sun and Moon and goes over them, and beyond them, by which they are ruled. So tell me what is the ground and root of all these words, names and things, for your branches are come out to the view openly, so give me your knowledge of your root, and every one of these names, things and words, from whence every one of them had their being, and their rise, and from whom and by whom they all sprang? Answer me these ye knowers and understanding ones, and men of wisdome and men of knowledge and men of learning; so you professing your selves; me give an answer if you be learned and taught of that that understands all roots, if not, let your silence acknowledge and speak, and declare the branches you have learned in the root, of which ye know not which branches every passer by hewes, but of your words, and terms and things, what be they?
16. What are the Artick and Antartick Circles, and what are the Summer and winter Tropicks?
17. What are the five Paralells, and what is a Zone, which you say are five in number?
18. What is the right and left hand of Astronomers, Cosmographers, and Poets?
19. What is the motion of the heavenly Orbs, and how know you there are ten?
20. What are the Fixed stars, and what are Vrsa Major, and Vrsa Minor, and what is the pole star?

21. What are all your Northern signes, Drago, Sepheus, the f •
ther of Ardromeda, Bootes Arcturus, Cignus Lyra, Orphei added to the stars for the benefit of muses? Delphinus placed among the stars by Ario the Harper; sagitta one of Hercules, weapons, Andromida placed by Minerva among the stars, Hercules Pagasus? &c. from whence comes all these words, from what ground and root, and who was the first Author of them, and what be the words, and are the words, and who was the first that gave forth all these names, and what was his name, and who was the first that learned them and of whom? and was he in the transgression, or out of the transgression, and did the Holy Ghost teach these words, and are the things of God to be spoken in these words, yea or nay? or are they words which mans VVisdome hath taught, that is below, earthly, sensual and devil • sh; and doth not these names words and things darken the knowledge? so then are they not the words, without the true knowledge; but the words that knowledge and understanding and VVisdome that comes to naught, is confounded, and is to perish swims in, so what root came they all from, the branches are discovered; they discover themselves, where the visible swims in; but that which discovers the root is invisible that runs too and fro, through hights and depths, which if you be in this, draw out your weapons and answer me these things, and let me see thy instrument which thou measures withall, bring it forth to the light, and come to it into the field vvhich is purchased novv in the day, and thou shalt have a place to bury thy dead.

22. VVhat are the stars of the Zodiack as Hiades, Ʋirgiliae, called also pleiades and Atlantides, and what is Maja the mother of Mercurie? also what is Castor & Pollux whom you call most loving bretheren, Ʋindemiator, Centaurus, Gammedes, &c.
23. What are the Stars you call Cetus Erichthonius? the river Eriddanus, orion, Hydra Ara the Meridional crown? &c.
24. What is Rosmical Acronical and Heliacal?
25. What are the two APSIDES which two Orbes of the planets do Encompass?
26. What is the Dragon of the Moon?

27. What is the Epicycle; and what is the Eccliptick line; and what the vertical point; who was the first that gave forth all these names and words to these things, and what was his name; and of whom did he learn, was he not a transgressor, or was he out of transgression, answer me; whether all these words in themselve • ? your branches fills the Ayre like a wood, and like a wilderne • s they make the earth whereby the Ayre is corrupted with them, therefore come now and tell me, and answer me who be called wise men and Schollars by your understanding and wisdom, the root of all these words and names, what is his name and the tree that hath born them all these branches; and whether or nay all these things and names and words have not been set up since the life hath been transgressed, and by the transgressor of it; Therefore what are these names, words and roots from whence they sprang? Answer me that, if any man can open his mouth, or if you be acquainted with your own countrey words, names, roots, fruits & what be they all? what is every one of these names before mentioned, and what is everyone of these words, and what is every one of the roots that bore them, and whether they be all differing one from another, or all one in the ground and main; & whether there is not a root that overturns the root, & branch, and name, & word? And whether there is not another name unto which every knee shall bow of things in heaven and things in earth; and is not that the wisdom of God, Answer me if you be awakened. And whether these words before mentioned are not them wch comes from the transgressor, which ground is ignorance, and they that live in them keeps people in ignorance, and Judges that all others be fools that are not in these words, names and terms, and things as they be in, and have learned; and whether or no they are not fools that learns that which the transgressor hath set up those names and words? And whether or nay their end is not in the flesh and out of the spirit which gives an understanding to know the ground of all words and names that from the root of ignorance
comes, and whether or nay in these names and things and words here is not a body which who steps into, out of the life, in the transgression; which if he go to learn the names, things and word • , they often brake their Brain and makes them besides their sences, and there comes to be swallowed and suckt up; and whether all these be not in the transgression out of the life of God that doth not destroy nature, And whether or no that which doth is not in the transgression (that which distracts and destroys) whether or nay that is not self that seeks the knowledge, the wisdom, the understanding that the transgressor, hath set up which doth load, burthen, bondage and destroy and bring into captivity; whether or nay that is not out of the truth that doth destroy, and not in the wisdom of God that preserves.

div.head: Questions about your Medicine.
div.p: 1. VVHat is the art of Medicine, and what is Medicine?

2. What are these words Physiologie, Pathologie, Senei •• i • k▪ Hygieinill, Therapeutical, Diaterical, Chyrurgical Pharma
••••••
• rganick, Anatomical, and who was the Author of them, and 〈◊〉 are their root?
3. 〈◊〉 is a Temperament, Innate and influent?

4. 〈◊〉 is a complexion Sanguine Cholerick Phlegmatick,
〈…〉 , and what is the ground of all these, and what is his Au •• o • , • nd what be these words all as they are in themselves, and 〈…〉 ▪
5. W •• t is the Innate heat, and what is the influent spirit.
6. What is the Vehicle of the faculties, what is the Child?

7. What are the Meseraicke veines, the Mesentery, Sanguification, and the Capillar veines, answer to these things every one in particular, if you have the spirit, that knowes spirits, who gives names to spirits?
8. What is Conagulation of Aliment, what is the Quinte-sence, and what is the generative, Alterative, and formative facultie.

9. What is the Corion, Amnios, Secondine, the Spermatick parts, the umbilical vessels the urachus, the Iliacke Branches, who gave all these names, and who was the Author of them, and what are all these things, and is not the same the cause that gives the names?
10. What is Diathesis, Anastomasis, Diapedesis and Diairesis, Rexis?

11. What is Erosion, Diabrosis, Emphraxis, obstruction, Stenochoria, constipation Thlipisis, compressure, Coalescence, descention, Sunizesis, Subsidence, rarity, density, what be all these things, answer to every particular of these things, and what they be all in themselves, these names and words?

12. What is Exarthrosis, Trauma, puncture, Thlasis and Thlasma contusion, rupture, fracture, Agma, Catagma, Teredon, Elkos, Apospasme, Podagra, Ophthalmie, what are all these things in themselves, and what was the first Author of them, and the first inventer of all these words, and who was he?

13. What is a Congenite, Endemial, and Epidemical, vernal, Estival, Autumnal, Hibernal Benigne, Maligne, acute, Salutary intermissive, proximate, which you call remite causes, prophasis which you call primative causes, Evident causes, occult causes, causes per se per accidence, and what is common, proper, positive, privative, non naturals, excretion, retention, to every particular of these words give an answer, and what be the root of all these words, and who be their Author?
14. What is a pure Pletoricke humour, and a Spurious, Cachochimicke humour?
15 What is natural Phlegme, preternatual, unsavoury Crude, acride; salt, and vitreous Phlegme.
16. What is Alimentary choller, Excrementitious and yellow choller, preternatual, vitelline choller, leeke green, Aeruginous and Blewish green, choller?

17. What is Melancholy Alimentary, Excrementitious, natual, Melancholy, and Melancholy Adust, what are these words, and what is the cause of all these things ye speak of, and who was the Author of them?
18. What is a fetulent excrement, a Juliginous vapour, what is the serious humour, a flux attraction Transmismission?
19. What is a virulent disease, and what is a Granary disease, and what repletion, manition, convultion, inflamation, Scyrrhus, Empyema?
20. What is a Symptome Cylosis?

21. What is an Atrophy, a cachexy, a Baclomia, a Malabacha hi • cock alientary, a caeliak affect, a diarhaea, a dysentary, a Tenesme, an
Illiak, Iscury, Dusuri, strangury, Diabetes, Gonohraea? these you call symptomes of the naturall faculty?

22. What is a Lypothemy or an Aphyxy, a Syncope, an Asphuxy, which you call Symptomes of the vital faculty, and what are these words, Apnoia, Dyspnoia, Dusopme, Asthma, Orthopnie, and who was the author of them, and what is the root?
23. What are these words which you call the Symptomes of Sight Amagrocis, Ambluopia, Muopia, Nutolopea, Marmarugasse?

24. What are these words which you call the symptomes of hearing, Barucoia, Ducecoia, Hypocephocis, Ecos and Sanignos? what taught you to speak all these names, what was the first Author of them, of all these names and termes, and what is the cause of these causes, and what are all these things in themselves?

25. What are these that you call Symptoms of the internal sences, Natural, preternatural, which you say proceeds from a Morbifique cause, which is a Cataphora, a Coma, Somnolent-vigilant, an Etasie a Phan • isme an Idea, a Delireum, a moderate delireum which you say the Greeks c • ll paraphrasune frensy and madnesse, and why wolfe-madnesse, and dog-madnesse and Badger-madnesse? and who was the first author of all these things, and what are the cause of them, and who was the Author of the words, and what are the words in themselves?

26. And why these words which you call Symptomes of the motive, faculty, animal, motion, Palsie, lastitude, tremos, and a convulsion universal, which you say is three-fold, which you call Emprosthones, Opisthotonos, Tetanos?

27. And what are these that you use in a Convulsion particular, aspasmas, Cynious, Trismos, Strabismos, aspasme, aphonia? what be all these things and the words in themselves; Answer, and who was the first author of them, and what is the root of them, and who was the Author, and what are the cause of all these causes ye speak of?

28. And what are all these following words, Tranlotes, Psellotes a vertigo, an incubus, a Lethargy, a Carus, a Catock, an Epelepsie an appoplexie? Answer, and who was the first Author of all these words, and what are the words, in themselves, and what be the root, and from whence and from what root did they come?

29. What are all these words you call Tactil qualities, Palpitation
Sypothymy, Catarrh, Caligo, albugo plerugion, what be these words in themselves, and from what ground did they come, from that ground which is the cause of these words yea or nay, and the cause of their causes?
30. The Aqueous humour what is it, and these words, Cataract, Hypopuon, Nuctolonia, Glaucoma?

31. VVhat is a sign, and these words you use about it, Diagnosticks, deloticks, Prognosticks, Anamnosticks, Pathognomonicks, Synedruons, Epiginomens, Epephanensens a fernacious Sediment? what be all these words in themselves, and what was the first Author of them, and what is their ground and root, answer me from whence the Author had them; from the holy Ghost that the holy Ghost teacheth, or the words mans wisdom doth teach?

div.head: Some Questions of some of your Termes in that you call Physicks or Physiology, together with your Metaphysicks.
div.p: 1. WHat is Physiology?
2. What is nature?
3. What are the principle and cause?
4. What is the affection of a natural body?
5. What is an active and passive principle?
6. What is matter? what is the first matter?
7. What is form? what is privation?
8. What is against nature, besides nature, above nature, according to nature?
9. What is a cause by it sell? and what by it self? and therefore what is an unversal cause; a particular cause a final cause?
10. What is a cause accident, or what is by accident; And therefore what is Fortune or chance?
11. What is 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or Act perfect or imperfect?
12. What is it to be in power, and what is to be in act?
13. What is the bound from whence, and what is the bound to which.
14. What is an Agent, what is a patient, And therefore what is it to be simply natural, and what according to something?
16. What is natural violent, and void of violence?
17 What is finite and what is infinite in Act and power?
18. What is vacuum or avoid?
19. What is according to former and what is according to Latter?

What is the ground of all these, and what is the ground of all these words and causes, and what is their ground and root; and whether or nay they do not proceed from that in which men that are in will, fall out about these words; and what are they in themselves; and whether or nay have not been all these words and things since the life was transgressed, and comes up, and out from ignorance and transgresses the life and witness of of God which will give an understanding, yea, or nay, answer me?

div.head: Of Metaphysicks.
div.p: 1. WHat is Metaphysicks?
2. What is being, and what an Essence, and what an existence?
3. VVhat is the internal principle of a substance, and external principle of a substance?
4. VVhat is it to be absolutely taken; and what to be taken by restriction?
5. VVhat is the manner of a being; and what is the being of reason, and what is a being by accident?
6. VVhat are universallity and singularity?
7. VVhat is the the principle of undeviding?
8. VVhat is a Prymary and Secondary manner of being?
9. VVhat is the manner of a being risen or gotten?
10. VVhat are Pryority and Posteriority?
11. VVhat is Perseity and velleity?
12. And what is the order of a being absolute, and what is the knowledge of a being according to us?
13. What is it to be together in the order of a being?
14. What is the Essence of universals which by the Philosophers so called, is called an Idea; likewise an universal nature?
15. What is an imperfect universal?
16. What is the order of dependance, or of the principle, and the Principiate or of the cause and the caused?
17. What is the order of causing in it self, or in respect of some manner which followes that order?
18. What is the Univocal producer or cause, What is the Equivocal producer or cause?
19. And what is Univocal and Aequivocal, and whence comes the word Logick?
20. What is a determining cause?
21. What is an intermediate end, or what is a principle or ultimate end;
22 VVhat is the order of the general cause and things caused, and what is special order of the same things?
23. VVhat is the more worthy, and what is the more unworthy cause?

Answer me all these things; vvhat be all these things as they are in themselves, and vvhat is the root and ground and Author of every vvord as they are in themselves distinct each from others; And vvhat and vvho vvas the founder of every one of these vvords and things and their cause, and vvhy these vvords and things, and vvhat be they? Ansvver to every particular; and give an ansvver of the root and Author of every vvord and thing, vvhat vvas it that hath borne them and brought them forth, and vvhether all these vvords be true vvords invented by mans VVisdome, or taught by the spirit of God, vvhich by it they must be fulfilled? Answer that yea or nay? and whether these words and things are not them which men wrangles and falls out about, and wrangles and j • ngels one with another about them? That Answer me.
24. VVhat are possibility, necessity; contingency, Faciliy and difficulty?
25. VVhat is the greater contingency, what is the lesser contingency?
26. VVhat is the order of Duration, and what of Quantity, and what of place?
27. VVhat are the measure of perfection, the measure Exemplar of application, and of Repletion?
28. VVhat is the order of cognation and union?
29. VVhat is the order of identity, and what is it?
30. VVhat is the order of union in essence, what is the order of union in respect of existence, and what is Identity of existence?
31. VVhat is the order of Diversity?
32. VVhat is the order of a Being especially taken?
33. VVhat is Relation in it selfe in respect of humane sence or knowledg?

And what is that that gives an understanding to know all true words from fals, such as are taught by mens wisdome, and such as are taught by the spirit, and what be every one of these words that be mentioned in themselves? and what is the root of every word, distinguish every word and every root that bears every word, for your branches are come forth?
34. VVhat is the doctrine of the signe and signification of Metaphisicks?

35. VVhat is the physical and natural signe, and what is the
•••• ical or possitive signe?
36. VVhat is a simple substance?
37. VVhat is the matter first, or simply considered, and what is t • e matter are respectively considered in Bodies?
38. VVhat is the Simular or Homogeneal part of a body, and what is the dissimular or Heterogeneal part of a body?
39. VVhat is a secondary being or accident, because you call Substance a primary being?
40. VVhat is a complex or a compound being, and what is the affection of a Complex being?
41. VVhat is the Cognate of a being, or the Image?
42. VVhat is the Opposite of a being, and what is the Simple opposite of a being, and what is the complex opposite of a being?
43. VVhat is [not a being] and that either simple not a being, or according to some thing, not a being?

44. VVhat is a [not being] complex according to some thing and what is a [not being] complex simply considered, is there not much jangling and strife about these words, and about these things, and is it not for want of being in the true understanding, and wisdome and knowledge, that comprehends the contrary wisdom • , knowledge, and understanding, and doth the understanding and knowledge and wisdome know in his own terms, and their understanding out of which comes all the difference, in phrases in expressions, in things and words; and what be all these things that be mentioned above, and what be all these words in themselves, and from what root and ground did each and every one of them come from, and what is the root that bears every word, for your branches, as said before, are come forth.
But now give me an answer of your roots, if you be in the understanding that comes not to nought, that gives to understand things, words, roots, from whence each comes, O come out of your holes?

45. What are all the Abstractive termes used in this your science, and what is the word abstract, and from whence had all these things their ground, and what was their root, and who was the author of all these things above mentioned, and who was the first Author and rise, and whether all these words were given forth by the teaching of the Holy Ghost above mentioned, and what is the root of every one of these words and things, and whether any of these words and things must be fulfilled by the spirit of God? and whether or no these vvords and things must dye of themselves and the root that hath borne them, and vvhether that vvhich doth discover roots and branches, cannot take the good and distinguish it from the root that bears the bad, and is not that the tree that bears true wisdome? Answer me.

div.head: A Few Questions about that which you call Ethicks, Politicks, & Oeconomicks, or Moral Phylosophy.
div.p: 1. VVHat is Ethicks, Politicks, and Oeconomicks?
2. VVhat is Theoretical, Phylosophy, and what is Practical Phylosophy?
3. VVhat is the Speculative, and what the practical Intellect?
4. VVhat is humane Felicity which you call the end of moral Phylosophy?
5. VVhat is Prudence and practical Phylosophy?

6. VVhat things are (per se) or of their own nature good or evil, or what is right reason, which you say discerns, and how for the saler judging thereof is the moral Law, so called, to be regarded, and how is this moral Law an expresse image of the Law Natural, and a compendium of moral Phylosophy, and what is the Law natural?
7. What are 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or things indifferent, which you say humane reason ought to get a faculty of discerning of, by use?

8. What are moral actions, their differences and principles, and what 〈◊〉
Affections and pleasures, and Grief which you call the objects of L • hi • ks, and what is an object? what be all these words in themselv • s as they are words, and from what roo • came they, and who was their root and their first author, and beginner? answer me, • or the branches doth discover themselves, and answer me wh • t is every particular root of these words, and what is all these words, answer me every thing; came they from the wisdom of men • te • ching, or the wisdome of God; Answer, yea or nay, who w • s the fi • st Author of them, Heathens or Saints, and whether or no Christians are to learn heathens words, and whether or no those that are called Christian • , that have gotten the heathens words, are wise and judge them fools that hath them nor, and whether or no they be in the fools state, that is lifted up in that which the heathens invented?
9. What is vertue and its kindes, by which, as by the meanes, men come to felicity, and what is a meanes?
10. How is that which is the subject in Sciences the end in Ethicks and other like disciplines? And what is an Analytical method wherein Ethicks ought to be delivered?

11. What are naturall Goods, which you call the Goods of the mindes, body and fortune, and what are the convenient habits of the minde, both speculative, and practical, and the actions proceeding from them, also pleasure as the companion of those actions? and how is the minde adorned, and perfected hereby?
12. How doth vertue rather depend on custome then nature?

What be all these words, from vvhence springs all this vvisdom understanding and knovvledge that gave them forth and invented them, and vvhat be all these things in their ground and nature, and vvhat was the nature of them, & the mother that bore them and the father that begot them, and vvhether or no these things, vvords and names, be not in the vvisdome belovv, in that part that distracts people out of the vvisdome of God? Therefore Answer everything in particular, and root of it, and what is the wisdome that brings all the whole creation into order, and whether all these words, terms or things are given forth from that, or in that which is from below?

13. What is Nobility and the Priviledges thereof, and how is it not a meer feigned thing, and how hath it a foundation in nature, and how is there a certain faculty in good men, & Gentle men to procreate children ingenious and inclinable to vertue; And whether it be custome which perverts that good nature and makes them degenerate from the ancient vertue of their family?
14. What is honour, and how is it rather in the honourer then in the honoured, and how doth it depend on the free will of the honourer?
15. What is the manifold forme of Good and Evil?
16. What is the Innate, and what Elicite Appetite?
17. What are Praise and Glory?

18. What is a Stoick, Epicurian, Platonick, Peripatetick Phylosopher, and what is Stoical, Epicurial, Platonical and paripateticall who was the author of all these names, and whether or no Christians that say they are spiritual, are to mingle themselves with their words of wisdome, that their wisdome hath taught, but what are these
words themselves, and who was the first inventer of these names, and who gave them the names, bring forth your record?
19. What are the divers Subordinate ends, and what is the Ultimate end in morality, and what is Subordinate, and what is Ultimate?
20. VVhence grew the divers opinions of moral Phylosophers about felicity?
21 What is Speculative felicity, and what practical felicity?
22. What is the sapiens or wisdome, where speculative felicity doth consist?

23. What is the summum bonum or the chiefest good, which is made the ultimate end in moral Phylosophy, and what Fecility or blessedness is, that is such a chiefest good? and how doth that felicity happen to none without 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or goods of fortune?
24. What is contemplation in moral Phylosophy?

25. How is the essence of felicity, placed as ye say 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
katakteesin in the habit of vertue and 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
katachreesin; in the operation thereof?

26. How are health, strength, vigor of the sences, wit, towardlinesse, liberty, friends, riches, &c. the instruments of felicity, and how are Nobility, honour, praise, glory, good name, Beauty and your 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 or fruitfulnesse in children, &c. the ornaments thereof.
27. What is that prudence whereby all moral vertues are knit together, and how without it none obtains practical felicity?

28. How are other beings besides God as it were steps whereby the mind is carried up to the contemplation of God, and how can none come to divine wisdom, but he whose mind moral virtue hath purged from the dregs of unreasonableness and passion. Answer all these things, and to every thing in particular, and give your first Author and ground, and root of every thing in particular, if you be in the wisdom of God, and whether or no amongst them that have these words there are not much confusion and jangling about them; so the root of every word and thing, and name bring out, and then things shall be seen beyond the Branches, answer me these, and then something will be spoken.
29. What are the principles of voluntary Actions?

30. What is the absolute, and what the comparative judgement of the practical intellect? and what is vellectie which followes the absolute judgement, and what is volition which followes the comparative?
31. What are the affections in general?
32. How are they the functions of the natural facultie?
33. What is moral pleasure and grief, and what is that pleasure which followes moral vertue and felicity, and what is the grief which follows moral vice?
34. What is common and natural pleasure, and what is proper and adventitious pleasure?
35. What are intellectual moral vertues?
36. What is intelligence, science, Sapience, Art and prudence, which you call the five Dianoetical vertues?
37. What is the Theoretical and what the Practical part of the mind?
38. What is the nature of moral vertue in general and particular?
39 What is the Efficient cause of moral vertue, which Galen, the stoicks and Socrates properly rendred not, and how is custome the Principle and immediate cause of manners and moral vertue?

40. What is moral piety or godliness, since you acknowledge the naughtiness of the Gentiles minds, had corrupted their knowledge of God, what is a Cardinal vertue, and how are they four, and how are fortitude, temperance, prudence, and Justice those four.
42. What is moral magnificence, and what magnanimity, and how are they moral virtues?
43. What is universal, and what particular justice, what is distributive, and what commutative Justice?
44. What is commitie, and urbanity, and heroicall greatnsse, and how are they moral vertues?
45. What is moral friendship, and how is it one meane to get and enjoy felicity?
46. What is perfect, and what is imperfect friendship, and what is friendship per se, and what friendship per accidens?
47. What is voluntary, and what is necessary friendship, what natural, and what political friendship?
48. What is a semi-vertue?
49. What is the will its acting with the judgement of reason, with indifferency, and with dominion of its own act?
50. What is monarchy, aristocracy, and democracie, which are called politique friendship betwixt a Magistrate and his subject.
51. What is the manifold friendship betwixt subjects, and how is the nature of society handled in politicks & oeconomicks?

Answer all these questions in themselves, and what they are in themselves, and what the words are and what was the root of them all, whether from a transgressor, or one out of transgression, & whether the words that mans wisdom teacheth or the words that the holy Ghost hath taught. Answer one from another, and speak to every word and thing, and the root of it that is queried of you, and then something you do, and shuffle not forth off the branches, they are already come forth, they are sprung up in the night, but now in this day of pruning let us see the roots; and now in the time of the day and light, let us see the authors and every one that hath made his wood and wildernesse where he hath laid in the night, therfore now is the day wherein every word and thing must be brought out to the light and branch, and the root hath born them all, therefore ye that say ye are wise men, Schoolars, and learned men, and are not the fools and novises, Now in the day light your wisdom appears, what was the root of every one of these names, roots and things? and what be every one of these in themselves? and who was the first author of them? and whether or no they are the words that mens wisdom teacheth, or that which the holy Ghost teacheth, me answer, yea or nay?

div.head: Of Theologie.
div.p: 1. WHat is Theologie and Divinity?
2. What is a divine?
3. What is a hand-maid to Divinity, and how are arts, sciences and tongues, hand-maids to Divinity?
4. What is a clergie, and what are clergie and laitie?
5. What is a sisteme of Divinity?
7. What is the original?

8. What is theologie of the Gentiles, which ye say was improperly so called, and is threefold, poetical or fabulus philosophical,
or natural and sacerdotal, or political theologie?
9. How is theologie truly so called archetipal and Ectypal? And how is ectipal theologie first, in Christ, Secondly, in his members, which you say is the effigies of the archetypal.
10 What is the theologie of the blessed and triumphant? and what the theologie of the travilers or mil • itant?

11. What is the principal of the being of theologie, & what the principle of knowing thereof which ye say is the word of God? and what is that word agraphon, unwritten before Moses time, and the word engraphon written since Moses time, & how is there no other principle of true theologie then the word of God written or the Scripture? and whether the Scriptures be the words and not the word? answer all these things, and to every particular querie, queried of you before mentioned? and what is every, word of these before mentioned, do not hip nor skip from them, answer every word in particular what the word is, and what was its root, distinguish each in its place that is queried of you; if you be in the wisdom that is below in the darknesse, and transgression, you cannot answer these queries, but if you be in the wisdom that is from above, that comprehends all grounds, roots, and branches, words, things and names with which they are seen and end, their wisdom speaks where that is?

12. What is the principle, and what is the ministerial Testimony of the Scriptures? and how is the ministerial the Testimony of the Church, and how is the testimony of the Church first in time, and the testimony of the spirit first in nature and efficacy?
13. What is canonical-scripture? And what is apocriphalscripture?

14. How is that question (to ask whether the Scripture be the word of God) unworthy a Christian? What be all these words before mentioned, whether or nay they have not come out from that body where mens wisdom doth teach words, and not from the words where all true words ends that are given forth by inspiration of the Almighty? answer all these questions before-mentioned, every particular of them, the words what they are themselves, and what is the ground, first author, and their root?
15. What is translation? and what is authenticall Translation?
16. What are the means of searching out the meaning of the Scriptures? one whereof you say is a logical analysis, and what is a logical analysis of the Scripture?
17. What is the primary or chief end of theologie, and what the subordinate end of theologie?
18 How is God known absolutely in his essence, and relatively in his persons?
19. What are Gods incommunicable properties, and what his communicable in Analogical effects?

20. What is the Trinity in Unity, and whether all these words be not of mens wisdom and teaching? answer to every particular querie and word that is queried of you here, and what was their first ground and root, and to the light bring it out, and the first author of them, and whether or no all this body hath not gotten up since the apostacy in the transgression, where mens wisdom teacheth words, and the words that the holy Ghost teacheth is foolishnesse to them, whether or no this is not so, answer me yea or nay?
21. What are the three persons in Trinity?
22. How are the persons subsistences of the Deity?
23. How is the trinity, not the number numbering, but the number numbred?
24. How is this opinion of the trinity, not onely a Church tradition, but a doctrine expressed in the Scriptures.

25. How is the word hypostasis which you acknowledge any singular substance, used metaleptically, (or by taking one thing for another, for a person, Heb. 1.3. since ye say a person is a singular, rational, compleat substance, and differing from another, by an incommunicable property, answer me this and all these queries and words, and tearms, and things before mentioned, what be the wisdom that hath taught them, and ground and root they are come from, and whether or nay they have not all come up-amongst Christians since the dayes of the Apostles, and learned of the Heathens that knew not God, that transgressed the life, that had nothing but their own wisdom to teach them, who was taught by their own wisdome, and whether that is not pleasing to a carnal man that knowes not the things of God?

26. • ow are the words persons, trinity, and homoousiou which ye grant are not found in so many syllables in the Scriptures,
yet agreeable thereto and profitably used in the Church?
27. How is a person of the deity, the essence of God with a certain manner of subsistence, and what is that certain manner of subsistence?
28. What are the essential, and what the personal works of God?
29. What are the works of God ad intra, or with in himself & ad extra or without himself?

30. What are the several wills, which Divines so called, make in God, as the will of his good pleasure, and the will of the sign, the antecedent will, and the consequent will, the absolute will, and the conditional will, the hidden will, and the revealed; and yet some say this distinction of the will of God is to be well observed, least real different and contrary wills are made in God, and grant that to speak properly there is none but the will of his good pleasure?

And whether all this be not in the body of divinity, and what is a body of Divinity? whether or no here is not presumption in these words which be of you queried, and what be all these words that be of you queried, and all these things answer to every particular word and thing, that is of you queried, what be the words, things, and the root they all spring from, and who was the author of every one of them in particular? come out to the light and answer (if it be in the divine ye be in) by which roots, branches, things, names, words are comprehended, discovered and seen, and answered, and confounds all the contrary, and fadoms all that is in the World?
31. What is the necessity of compulsion, and the necessity of changeablenesse in the decree or will of God, how doth not the decree of God take away contingency in second causes?
32. What is the General decree, and what is the special decree of God?

33. What is predestination to the end, and predestination to the means, which distinction you say ye make for the weakness of your understanding; how is predestination an absolute decree, and a not absolute decree of God?
34. How is sin not the cause of reprobation but the cause of reprobabillity?

35. What is theanthropos, and what is hypostatical union, since ye say the words prothesis, prognosis, and proorismos, are sometimes used for one and the same thing? why for teachings sake do you distinguish, the first to be Gods purpose of saving, the second to be his free benevolence, whereby he acknowledgeth his own for his; And the third to point out a predestination to Christ, and other means of Salvation besides Christ the light of the World?
36. How is Christ the cause not of election, but of salvation, and how is unbelief not the cause of reprobation, but of damnation?
37. How is damnation not the end of reprobation?
38. Why for teachings sake, as you say, do you make two acts in reprobation, as praeterition and predamnation?

39. Why must men in searching out their election, by an analyticall method, proceed from the meanes of Execution, to the decree, and what is an analyticall method, in searching out election, and why must in be by a Syllogism • , answer all these Queries that is Queried of you, that is laid down by you, that is fetched out of your own field, where you labour, and what be every word and thing in themselves, and what are the words, and what was their root, and whether or no here is not much confusion in all these things and words, and distraction and confusion amongst your selves about them, and whether or no they are not words that the wisdome of men hath taught, and entiseth others that be the learners; and the first Author and Inventer of them, was he not a transgressor, or were the words taught by the Holy-Ghost, answer me every particular name, word, thing, Querie, and what is the root of them all?

40. How are Angels in a place not circumscriptively, but definitively? What be all these things in themselves, what be all these words as different one from another, what is the root of every one of them in their particulars, and who was the first Author of them, and whether they are not the words •… f mens wisdom, or whether they are the words of the Holy Ghosts teaching, & what is an Angel, & what is Adam, & what 〈…〉 the tree of knowledge of good and evill, an outward tree,
yea or nay, and what was its fruit outward, yea or nay? let all these things be answered, words and names, and the root of them all, and come out to the light in this the day, and be not like the venemous Beasts that wanders about in the night, when the day appears they go into their Dens, but when the day appeares, men go to their labours.

41. Since ye acknowledge Gods providence (which you call his actuall providence) to be that whereby he doth preserve and govern all things, how do things thereby necessarily come to pass, onely with the necessity of Mutability and not of constraint?
42 What is the Primary Subject of the Image of God, and what the secondary Subject of that Image?
43 What are the naturall Gifts of the Image of God, and what the supernaturall gifts thereof?

44. Since you say there was such clearness of understanding in man before his fall, that he could give every thing a name sutable to its nature, what use is there of any termes of art invented by man in the fall?
45. How is man renewed or in the state of grace free from evill, and free to good, by Gods grace, but imperfectly?
46. How is sin expressed or as you say defined to narrowly, by thought, word or deed?
47. How would not God have the first sin committed, and how would he have it committed?
48. What was the prokatarkical, and what the proeegoumenal cause of the first sin?

49. What are those certain degrees whereby Adam fell from God, not at once, but by little and little, all which parts or degrees of falling ye say thou shalt rightly call a transgression of the law of nature; and what was that law of nature, which he transgressed against?
div.q:
What are all these words, whether or nay they are not the words that the wisdom of man hath taught, and whether or no they come not from the root that transgresseth the life, or whether or no they are the words that the holy Ghost hath taught, answer me if you can or dare venture, what every particular of these words is, and from what center and ground they come from, and what is the root of them; for much branches have discovered themselve •… from the imaginations, therefore the root of all these words and things shew forth, and the root of the imagination, and what is the tree that must be o •… down, that bears not fruit to God, and hath not this tree a wisdom, a knowledge, an understanding, & would not this wisdom teach words, which is foolishness
with the wisdom of God, which must be confounded, and doth not that which confounds confound. words to which it taught, answer me, for you have tongue enough sometimes, let us see now if it can wag, ye doctors, ye learned men, let us see if it be the tongue of the learned, and what is the of tongue the learned?
div.p: 50. How is the diversitie of actual sins taken from the matter, from the form, from the Efficient cause, from the subject and from the object?
51. How from adjuncts is a thing sinful by it self or by accident?
52. How doth sin aginst men hurt their superiours, inferiours and equals, and what is a superiour and an inferiour among men?
53. What are those four degrees of death wherein the misery of sinful man is contained?

54. Why call you the Law of God the moral Law, and in what respect doth it differ from the Law placed in the first man Adam, whereof you say the heathens have remainders of, and what is the remainder of the first Law?
55. What is that greater Emphasis which is in a negative precept, then is in an affirmative, and how doth an affirmative precept bind semper or alwayes, but not ad semper or to alwayes?

56. Where find you such a definition of the Gospel in the Scriptures, and as you give of it, to wit the Gospel is a joyful message or doctrine of the Son of God, sent into the world, that taking on him humane nature, he might undergo, the curse of the Law in our stead or place, and by most perfectly obeying the same, might deserve for us eternal life.

57.
