What are all your various agreements and disagreements between the Law and the Gospel as their agreement in the chief efficient cause there differing in outward instrumental causes, saying also the law was knowen to men naturally but the Gospel by Gods gracious Revelation, their agreement in the common matter, their differing in the proper matter, their agreement in their commun form, their differing in the proper form, their agreement in the chief end, their differing in their proper ends, their agreement in their common object, their differing in their proper object, their agreeing in their common adjunct, and their differing because by accident, and through mans infirmity, the Law without the Gospel is insufficient to salvation.

58. How doth it appear by this comparing the Law and Gospel together in what sort they are opposite, and subordinate one to another, and what is the opposition, and subordination of the Law and Gospel?

59. How is it, that since ye say, what righteousness the Law requireth, that the Gospel holds forth to a believer, yet ye say we cannot fulfill the Law in this life, but the regenerate by the gift of Sanctification do begin to obey it? what be all these words, names which be Queried of you, distinguish them, and what is the root of every particular, and whether or no there is not much confusion in them, and whether or no there is not the words of mans wisdom that it doth teach; so answer every particular word in themselves, and who was the Author of them, and the first rise, and what the words are, and what he vvas that vvas the first Author of them, answer every one of these words in their root, and whether they came from a transgressor or from a Saint, give me the ground, the root, the Author of every word and thing if you have the tongue of the learned that can speak • in.

60. What are all the termes about Christs incarnation as you call it, as Incoatatively and Terminatively, and Sunthetically, personal union, that Christs Humane nature hath not a peculiar, subsistence or any other then that [toulogou] whereby he differs from all other men; That its expedient for teachings sake to shew how his humane nature was united to the Son of God, and how not united; Not united sunoudioodoos, nor ousioodoos & dicasticoos only, not sketicoos, and not mustikoos onely, that is as Christs dwells in the faithful. Nor Sacramentally, as he is in the supper, but it is united Hupostatikoos which you expound personally, which personall union ye say is Atreptoos, adiaretoos a Sugnchutoos and achoristoos; what be all these words, whether there is not confusion in them, and whether or no these words was taught by the holy Ghost, that are Queried of you above mentioned, or by the wisdom of man out of the truth, and what is the center the root and ground from whence every thing and word came, come up and appear, and answer if you be come into that which knowes hights and depths, changeable words and roots, and withering branches and roots; and branches, and words that shall not change nor end, but be fulfilled in that, and by that which hath no end?
61. What is the verball Communication of properties, and what the real, which Communication you say is one effect of three of the Personal union?
62. How is the Father the efficient cause of Christs Mediatorship [Kat'exocheen]
63. How is not onely whole Christ, but the whole of Christ the subject of his Mediatorship?
64. What is the difference between Christ being a Mediator by merit, and by efficacy?
65. What is eternal life privatively taken, and what positively taken, and how is Christs payment of punishment the cause of the former, and his perfect righteousness the cause of the latter?
66. What is Christs Original righteousness, and his Actual righteousness, and how is his Original righteousness opposed to Original sin?

67 How do they that say Christ laid down his life for all, stretch his sufferings further then is meet, and how know you that by all & every man whom Christ is said in the scripture to give his life a ransome for, is meant Metonymically, and of genera singulorum or kinds of all, but not of singula generum, or all of the kinds? Answer these queries, and is there not confusion and contradiction in these words of yours, what are all these words distinct one from another, Answer, And what is the root of every one of these words, and who was the first Author, and are they not words that mans wisdom hath taught, and not as the holy Ghost hath taught, distinguish the one from the other, was he a transgressor that gave them forth the first Author, or was he a Saint led by the spirit of God, or had you them first revealed to you by the spirit of God, or had you them out of old Books and Histories, the words that mans wisdom hath taught below out of the life, in the transgression, where all confusion and distraction is? Answer to all these things before mentioned.
68. What is Christs Essential Kingdom, and what his personal Donative, and Oeconomical Kingdom, since you say he shall Administer his Oeconomical Kingdom for ever?
69. How are not all men, nor the Eiect onely, but some of all mankind, called to grace?
70. How have some an outward and Analogical Communion of the Covenant of Grace, whereby they are reckoned for Gods people, but not so in truth?
71. What is a Sacramental, and how is that word not unfitly applyed to the signes of grace, what are the signes signifying, exhibiting, applying and sealing in your Sacraments?

72. What are the effects of Sacraments, and if a confirmation and sealing of Justification, and sanctification as you affirm, how are they common to those that are not the elect, as well as to the
Elect, and if they are proper onely to the Elect, as to the thing signified, how can they be common to others, as to the sign, since the sign was to shew forth the thing signified?
73. Hovv is John and Christs Baptisme [re ipsa] as you say or in very deed the same?
74. How is one end of Baptism with water a seal of receiving and Implanting into Gods family and of regeneration?

75. How have infants faith no otherwise then as they have reason, that as ye say not in the fruit, but in the root and seed, not in the first, but second act, and how is the reason otherwise between the infants of unbelievers and persons in Covenant, and who are the seed, and who are in Covenant?

76. How is sprinkling of water used in the place of plunging, and how do you believe that the Apostles in Baptizing whole families had the same tender respect to infants in colder Countreys as you say you have? what are those formal words as you call them which you use in Baptisme, saying, I Baptize you in the name of the Father, &c. whether to Baptize in or into (as the word is) the name, be formal?
77. How is the participation of the body and blood of Christ sealed to Christians in breaking of bread, and how is it Metonymically called the Eucharist.

78 How know you that breaking of bread is not a thing indifferent, and what it the body and blood of Christ? how know you that when Christ said this is my body, his meaning this was the Sacrament of my body?

Whether or no here are not lies in these words and things of yours and confusion and darkness, your selves by your own words which your own wisdom teacheth you, what is every one of these words in particular queried above mentioned of you; and who was the Author of every word, and the root, what is that of every word and thing that is queried above, answer to the thing, and whether or no they are not the words and things that mans wisdom hath taught, which knowes not the root of the true wisdom nor the Kingdom of God wch hath no end, answer these things of you be in the wisdom of God, if not, let your mouth stop and confound you; and your words, and it that taught you, and if you all know the root of every word and every thing, now if you tell what another man sayes is the root, and root of your words, then I ask what was the root of that man, that
made him to speak them forth, vvas it from the vvisdom that man teacheth, or from the wisdome that the Holy Ghost teacheth, Answer me that; if you become to that which doth reveal, savour and gives to understand?

79. What is the visible and invisible Church, and what is the nature of the visible Church, and how is it considered in it selfe, or oppositely in respect of the false Church and Katachrestikoos, or improperly, or how is the visible Church a company of persons commonly called, both of the Elect and Reprobate, what is the ambiguety of the name of a visible Church, as propely so called, for the called or universal Church throughout the world strictly taken as the English, French, Dutch, or Helvetian, and how is a national Church said to be strictly taken, or what is a national Church or most strictly taken for a representative Church of Pastors & Elders, and what is a representative Ch. & how are they a Ch. representative?

80. How doth the forme of the Church consist in a two-fold communion, and what is the forme of the Church, and how doth Christ communicate his vertues to the members of a visible (some being Reprobates) as the head doth to the members?
81. How hath the word Catholick Church a three-fold signification?

82. What is that inherent holinesse of the Church in this life which is not perfect, and how doth Christ cover that imperfection with his own perfection, if his perfection be not in his Church, and how is that imperfect holiness, perfect by a hope that it shall be perfect.

83. How are the notes of the visible Church, the pure preaching of the word of God, with the lawful administration of the Sacraments, and where is this pure preaching of the word of God to be sound, and what is the lawfull administration of the Sacraments? And what are those accidentall things, wherein those notes do more agree to one Church more then an other, what is the ordinary or extraordinary administration of the Church, answer all these things, every particular, as they are of you queried, and what are they every word and thing in it selfe, and the root and ground of them all in every thing, and word, and root, and ground of them all, shew forth each in their place, and who was the first author of them all; and whether the words and things of God is to be spoken in the words that mans wisdom doth teach, and whether or no these be not the words, or most of them, which
mans wisdome hath taught, and are not of the words which the holy Ghost teacheth, distinguish every word, and thing and name one from another, and what every thing and name is that is above mentioned?

84. How are the gifts of Prophecy, Tongues and Miracles, marks of the extraordinary Ministers of the Church, and how these extraordinary gifts being taken away, an ordinary Ministry succeeded, Answer this?

85. How came those gifts to be taken away, and how are the ordinary Ministers of the Church instructed, & called by ordinary, meanes and what are those ordinary meanes? and what is Bathkol which you say is the daughter of a voice, what is the daughter a voice, and by whom was she begotten?
86. What are ordinary Pastors, Doctors or Teachers, Presbyters and Deacons of the Church?

87. How comes this difference between Pastors and Doctors to be, that the first are chief over the Church, these over the Schools, they in moving, these especially in teaching their hearers; Answer these and the cause and the matter, these things be according to the queries, and bring out your strength and reasons, and speak to the things?

88. What are Schooles and Ʋniversities, in which Doctors are professors of Theologie? and what is a professor of Theologie Ans. & who was the first author of Schools and Colledges, to make Ministers since the daies of the Apostles, that men was made by the will of God?

89. How is God the chief cause of the call of ordinary Ministers, and how doth he call ordinary Ministers inwardly, and indue them with his gift; and what are those gifts, and whether Schoole-learning be not rather gotten by humane study and industry, then gifts?
90. What is a Ministerial call of ordinary Ministers, and how is it by the whole Church, or at least by a representative Church?

91. How are examination election, and confirmation required to the lawfull call of ordinary Ministers, and how can such ordinary Ministers appoint a good order in the Church, judge of doctrine, and controversies, and exercise the power of the keyes, which is to have what they bind on earth bound in heaven, which were the actions of Saints and Ministers, endewed with
those which you call extraordinary gifts? Answer all these things in themselves what they be, every thing in themselves, and the root of every word of these above queried; and what is every word in themselves, and the root they came from; so to every particular querie, and every particular word; give your answer, who is the author of them?
92. What is a Synode, or Presybtery of ordinary Ministers, and that either Oeconomical, national or provincial, Classical, and parochial, and what is the Prolocutor of a Synode?
93. What is the Ecclesiastical and what is the political government of the Church, and how doth the Magistrate govern the Church politically?
You say there is a threefold word, Hypostaticos, Eudiathetos, Prophoricos, give the root of all these words and their author?

94. How are Magistrates nurses to the Church, as they are keepers of both Tables, and what is a keeper of both tables, and how are they nurses to the Church, as they preserve the Church and Schools; and do they preserve the Church or the Schools of natural learning?

95. How is a Church counsel to be called by a believing Magistrate, and how is an unbelieving Magistrate in such a case to be sought unto by an humble book, and how if he be such an open enemie necessity so requiring, may be celebrated by the common-censent of the Church, and not else, was this agreeable to the Apostles?
96. What is the President of a counsel, and what the Political and Ecclesiastical president of a counsel, and what is the scribe of a counsel? and why so many scribes as presidents?

97. What are these private men which you say are not plainly excluded from a counsel, who may be present at the handling of doctrine, but not at the knowledge of the scandals or offences? And what is a private man in the Churth, and how doth charity cover scandal from such private men? Answer all these things particularly, and all these things and words and names, and whether or no they are agreeable to the Church and Apostles, yea or nay, let us know your ground, let us know the root of all these things, words and names before queried, and what was every one of these words, and what was its root?

98. How is the office of a Political President to gather the counsel
to defend it, being gathered, to forbid all force and disorder, to promulge or set forth its decrees lawfully made by his authority and to compell those that refuse them, and what are the lawfull decrees of a counsel?
99. How is the office of an Ecclesiastical president to propose the question, to moderate the disputing by the counsel of the assessors to ask the opinion and bring the decrees by notaries into acts?

100. What is common and what is special calling; how doth the Schools name it Actual Election, Effectual calling, and inward calling; what is the Efficient cause, what the impulsive, and what the instrumental cause of the special calling; how doth novaters or new ones falsely affirme, that sufficient grace is given to all?
101. What are these Novators or new ones?
102. How doth God call some before baptism, some in baptism, and some after baptism, which you speak of?
103. How is common calling often times onely outward, and special calling inward?
104. VVhat are the Immediate, and what the Mediate effects of special calling?
105. What is faith Metonomically taken for sound doctrine, historical faith, temporarie faith, faith of miracles, historicall faith and saving faith?

106. How is the instrumentall cause of saving faith, in persons of ripe yeares, ordinarily the word of God which ye call the words? Answer all these here queried of you, what are all the words, and what are all the names, and what are all these things, and who was the author of them, and who was the root; distinguish every thing in it selfe, their author and root? So answer every one of these words and names and things, and what the words and names are; whether or no it is from the words that the wisdome that man hath taught, or the words that the holy G • ost hath taught; Answer these if you have that that can give a distinction?
107. What is the justification which ye say by a forreigne signification is to absolve and loose from sin; and to pronounce just or righteous by God; without inherent or inward Righteousnesse?

108. What is the Righteousnesse of the cause, and the righte
•… usnesse of the person, perfect or begun, which you call inchoate? •… nd what is perfect legal, and what perfect Evangelical righte
•… usnesse? And how is Inchoate righteousnesse, that which the spi
•… it begins in the faithful in this life, and perfects in another life, •… nd how is the perfect righteousnesse of Christ, the gift of justifi
•… ation, and begun righteousnesse the gift of sanctification; and what are all these things in themselves, and who was the Rise •… f them all; and the root of them all? Answer me, and distinguish •… hese words which were taught by mens wisdome, from those •… at the H • ly Ghost doth speak; and give a distinction of the one •… om the other, and every particular querie word and name and •… nd thing in it above mentioned? bring forth your answer to •… he light.

109: What are all your causes of justification, as the Efficient •… ause actively understood; the procegoumenal cause Prokatertical
•… ause and the instrumental cause?

110. How is this phrase as you call it, we are justified by faith
•… tonimically, and is as much at to say, we are justified by the •… erit of Christ apprehended by faith?

112. What is the matter of justification actively taken, and •… hat is the matter passively taken, and what is the forme thereof •… ctively understood, which you say is an imputation of all Christs •… tisfaction, whereby its wholly ours, no otherwise then if we had •… erformed it our selves?

113. How is the cause of justification for teaching sake exprest 〈…〉 two Acts; Remission of sins, and imputation of Righteous
•… esse, or an abjudging of sinnes, and adjudging of perfect righte
•… usnesse; and how are these two in subject and time the same, and •… et in very deed distinct?

114. What is the forme of justification passively taken? How is •… ustification imputative perfect and equall in all believers; give 〈…〉 in your answer to all these things, words and names, and each •… ound & root that hath borne them, and what they are in them
•… lves and who was the Author; distinguish every name, every •… ord, every thing, their Author, distinguish of these words, •… ames and things?
115. How doth sanctification accompany justification as light doth the Sun?
116. How is it to sanctifie, to appoint things from a prophane to holy uses, and habitually to make holy?
117. How are people commanded in the first sence to sanctifie the Sabbath day?

118. How must men in the sanctification of the Sabbath day discerne between to [eethikon] or that which is moral, and to [tupikon] that which is ceremoniall, and how was that ceremonial, that the seventh day should be precisely sanctified; and how is that moral, that one day in the seven should be appointed for Gods worship, and how doth the Church sanctifie the first day by Christs example, who ye say sanctfied it by his Resurrection and appearing, and how doth he thereby sanctifie it, and what is the word moral? give us in your answer to all these words, names and things, and what is the root of them all, and who was the first Author of them, and distinguish the one from the other, if you be men of understanding to put a difference and distinguish?

119. What are feast daies of Christians, and how are they called things a kinne to the sabbath, and how are such feasts in any sence not will Worship, but appointed for the remembrance of the benefits of Christ?
120. How are Regeneration, renewing, convertion penitence, resipicence and glorifying, all which (in sanctification) ye say is called ambiguous, or doubtfull words?
121. What is the efficient cause of sanctification commonly taken, and its efficient cause singularly taken, and in respect of the terme?
122. What is the inward Impulsive cause, its Prokatarktical, its Instrumental, both outward and inward, to which ye say also extraordinary meanes do happen?
123. What is the matter of sanctification, what is its forme and how expressed by two acts?

124. What is that Sanctification which is not perfect in thi •… life? Answer all these things as they are in themselves, and wha •… are all these names and words, and what was the root of them, an •… whether or no there is not confusion amongst you, and in the • , these words of yours? Answer me, if you be in the life and wisdom of God, what root every one hath its Name, and what it proceeded from?

125. How doth Sanctification and Justification differ first in their Genus or kind, and how doth the righteousnesse of the first belong to the predicament of qualitie, the other to the predicament of relation; Secondly in their forme, as faith in justificatio • as a hand laies hold of Christs Righteousnesse, but sanctification is considered as the principle root of Good; Secondly you say in justification sin is taken away, onely as to guilt and punishment, but in Sanctification its abolished by little and little, as to its existence: Thirdly, in justification Christs righteousnesse is imputed to men, in sanctification a new and inherent Righteousnesse is infused; Thirdly in their degrees, for say you, justification is one individual perfect, and equally happening to all, but Sanctification a successive act, and in some more, and some lesse; Answer, what be all these words, termes and names that are queried here, and things, give us an answer, what be they all in themselves, and what the root of every word of them is, and name, and thing, and terme, and whether they must end in the life or out of it, whether these words, things, termes in the queries above mentioned was given forth from the Holy Ghost, or words of mens wisdomes teaching, distinguish the one from the other, and what was the root of mans wisdome, teaching words, and who was the first author of it, and out of what had it its beginning, and out from whence did it come? Answer, with that which doth not transgresse, what all these things, words be in themselves and whether or nay there be not lies and confusion in these words that are queried of you, which be your own words?

126. What is the efficient cause of Christian Liberty commonly taken and singularly taken; what is its instrumental cause, its matter which hath the reason of a subject, and its matter about which it is conversant, and how is its forme expressed, in divers conditions by reason of the variety of objects?

127. How is that Christian liberty that in this life which wholly frees not from the inhaesion or indwelling of sin in this life & how is a man free from the guilt and dominion of sin while he is not freed from the sin? What be all these words, things and names, and from what wisdome came they from, the wisdom of God, or from the wisdome below, that teacheth words, and mixeth with scripture words it self, and what are all these words and names in themselves, and what is their root, and who was the
of them, distinguish every particular of their names, author, and root by themselves, who was the father of them?

128. How is the consuming of Anti-christ by the breath of Christs mouth, the ruin only of Rome? and how is her ruin the only desolation and burning up of the whore? Answer, what are all these things, words, Anti-christ be wholly destroyed, when Rome is destroyed, is there none against Christ, but at Rome? doth not every one that hates the light, which Christ hath enlightned every man that cometh into the world hate Christ, & so Anti? Therefore answer all these things in their particular, and distinguish each from the other, and what is the name, and every word, and the root of every one of them which they came from, distinguish one from the other?
129. What is Phylology and a Phylologist?
130. Whats a Compendium of Divinity, what an exposition and an expositor?
131. What are common places of Divinity, what is a text, and a textuary?
132. What is a Symbolum or Creed, or what is a Harmony of confession?
133. VVhat is a Catechism?
134. What are Institutions or introductions of or into Divinity?
135. What is a Paraphase, what a Metaphrase, and what a cataphrase?
136. What is Orthodox and Orthodoxal? VVhats an Antiquerie, what a Bachellor and Master of Arts?
137. And what a Bachellor and a Doctor of civil Law, physick and divinity?
138. What is a Graduate, and an under-graduate?
139. What is an Academie, and Vniversity, and what is Academical? and how are Academies the Nurseries of good learning, and how the eyes of the land?

140. And what is a Reformed Church, what be all these things, what be all these names and all these words, and expressions and things that are above queried of? Answer every particular word name and thing and expression, and let us see if you see now in the time of the day, let us see if your eye sight be not the same in the day, that its in the night, and in the night that its in the
day? Answer the ground and the root of all these names and words, what was it, and w • o was the auther and first setting them forth, and inventing them? Therefore every name, every word every query give us in your answer, ground and root, and author, and speak to the thing, which be your own words, and let us see whether you be master of them, that you have power over your tongue; so to the things and words and names, answer, and his name, and the first setter of them up; and give you in the root and Author to the above mentioned?

And what is Divine, and whether that which is divine doth not comprehend all that which is not divine, the things and names and words and their root? was not Cain a vagabond that built a city? and was not he the first that kild about worship and sacrifice, are not all things corrupted and languages, by the words of mens wisdome, and lost the simplicity of the purest of them? what was the first speech that was upon the earth in the World, had Adam the same speech in the fall that he had before the fall? whether or no there were so many languages when Babel was confounded as there is now at this day? Answer ye learned men, and if not; how many have come up since, who are they, and what be they, and hovv many languages and speeches have been upon the earth, and are there now, and what was the language before Babel, and whether any did keep the language at that time, and whether or no all was not confounded at that time, yea or nay? give us your answer, and whether or nay tongues be the original, and languages which goes no further then Babel, and whether or no tongues are not natural, and whether or no the beast, the false Church, the great whore and Babylon, and Pilate hath not power over them; and whether or no the Original hath not power over the beast, Dragon and false Church; and cemprehends them, and sees before they were? and whether or no people must not be redeemed out of the tongues and languages, being confounded into them, and whether or nay they that be come into the word into the beginning, are not redeemed out of them, and cannot say that tongues are the original, which they be not redeemed out of?

And whether Hebrew, Greeke and Latine be not natural as well as Spanish, English, French, and Dutch? and whether or no here is not a confusion among tongues, in exalting naturals above naturals,
tongues above tongues, that say tongues are the original which are confounded, and which are the tongues that are not confounded? and who was the first rise of Latine, and the first rise of Greek, and whether they were before Babel was confounded? And whether all languages, tongues and speeches be not corrupted with the pride and invention of their own, as they are languages, or tongues, or speeches of themselves? whether any one can say he hath the original if he be not in that which is before tongues and languages was? and whether or no tongues doth not stand in the confounding part, and in the natural that will alter, and whether the life suffered not when tongues came up, and whether or no tongues were not set a top of Christ • he life?

And whether or no as all men as they are in their tongues, are they not natural men, which cannot know the things of God, or the original, and not see so far as Moses which saw before Babel, and whether or nay being confounded into naturals if they be natural, whether they that be spirituall be not redeemed out of the Natural, and do not come before they were, and whether or no they were not gone (that God confounded) from the life in their own selves, before they were confounded into their languages and tongues? and whether or nay they that are come into the word of God, into the beginning, doth not comprehend all tongues, and Babel the beginning of them, and Pilate which set them a top of Christ, and Babylon the false Church, and the Beast and the false Prophet, and the Devil who is out of the truth, with the word which lives and abides for ever, which comprehends all that which lives not, endures not for ever?

And whether or no there is not a pride in all Languages that must be stained and brought down, as they are in themselves, and whether or no they that are redeemed, are not redeemed out of all Languages and tongues, and what were the names that Adam gave to every creature before the fall, and whether they be the same now, that be in the Latin, in the English, in the Greek, in the Hebrew, and other tongues and Languages, and whether or no all things are not degenerated from its first nature, answer these things if you have the word by which all things were created? yea or nay? and which of them is the Language, tongue and speech they were spoken in, answer, if you be the Minsters of
Christ, and have the tongue of the Learned, you are able to answer doubts, and resolve Questions, and instructors of those that oppose themselves.

TO every particular name, and thing, and word answer, and what was the ground and root of every one of these particular words and names, and what was the cause of all these causes, and who was the first Author and setter up of all these Arts and Sciences, and what was his name, and what was his root, and from whence had he his his beginning? and so answer what all the words be in themselves, and whether they be the words that mans wisdom hath taught, or the words that the holy Ghost hath taught, and whether or nay they have sprung from a root that is holy or a root that is unholy? And whether or nay all causes of diseases, need of teaching doth not spring from disobedience, and whether or nay all that doth teach, that teaches in the wisdom of God, is not from a holy root, and hath that that comprehends all, unholy roots and words proceeding from the unholy root, and the cause of all causes, is not he that is in the wisdom of God in seeing and feeling and knowledge of these? and whether or nay all you seven in your seven Arts, and seven Sciences to whom these are directed, has not spoken these words and these things, in strange words as are in this Book through your Arts and inventions of your wisdom; through that every Art and Science to make a Trade, and to keep people blind by your high expressions; therefore now I querie of you, whether or nay you have all these seven Arts and Sciences, whether you know all these words in your Arts and Sciences? whether you know these words, and whether you be perfect in your Trade, and if so, what was the Author of every particular word in it selfe, and what are the words in themselves, and what is every particular root in it self, and so to every thing, & to every word, to every cause, and the cause of every cause, and the first that set up these seven Arts and Sciences, and whether an Art is not an invention, and whether an Art be not a Trade, and so what vvas the root that those first did spring and come forth from, from a good fountain and a holy root, ansvver, yea or nay these things follovving, every particular, ansvver to the thing it self, its name, the vvord, the cause, and vvhatsoever is queried of you in the Book.
